chapter.title: Getting Started with &DSCL;s
chapter.para: This chapter introduces you to the concept and usage of &DSCL;s or &DSC;s for short.

section.title: Why Package Software with RPM?
section.para: The RPM Package Manager (RPM) is a package management system that runs on Red Hat Enterprise Linux. RPM makes it easier for you to distribute, manage, and update software that you create for Red Hat Enterprise Linux. Many software vendors distribute their software via a conventional archive file (such as a tarball). However, there are several advantages in packaging software into RPM packages. These advantages are outlined below.

varlistentry.term: Install, reinstall, remove, upgrade and verify packages.

listitem.para: Users can use standard package management tools (for example Yum or PackageKit) to install, reinstall, remove, upgrade and verify your RPM packages.

varlistentry.term: Use a database of installed packages to query and verify packages.

listitem.para: Because RPM maintains a database of installed packages and their files, users can easily query and verify packages on their system.

varlistentry.term: Use metadata to describe packages, their installation instructions, and so on.

listitem.para: Each RPM package includes metadata that describes the package's components, version, release, size, project URL, installation instructions, and so on.

varlistentry.term: Package pristine software sources into source and binary packages.

listitem.para: RPM allows you to take pristine software sources and package them into source and binary packages for your users. In source packages, you have the pristine sources along with any patches that were used, plus complete build instructions. This design eases the maintenance of the packages as new versions of your software are released.
You can add your package to a Yum repository that enables clients to easily find and deploy your software.
Using a GPG signing key, you can digitally sign your package so that users are able to verify the authenticity of the package.

section.para: For in-depth information on what is RPM and how to use it, refer to the Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 Deployment Guide or the Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5 Deployment Guide.

section.title: What Are &DSCL;s?
section.para: With &DSCL;s, you can build and concurrently install multiple versions of the same software components on your system. &DSCL;s have no impact on the system versions of the packages installed by any of the conventional RPM package management utilities.

listitem.para: &DSCL;s are distributed as a set of several components, which provide their full functionality without overwriting system files.

varlistentry.term: Are designed to avoid conflicts with system files

listitem.para: &DSCL;s make use of a special file system hierarchy to avoid possible conflicts between a single &DSCL; and the base system installation.

varlistentry.term: Require no changes to the RPM package manager

listitem.para: &DSCL;s require no changes to the RPM package manager present on the host system.

varlistentry.term: Need only minor changes to the spec file

listitem.para: To convert a conventional package to a single &DSCL;, you only need to make minor changes to the package spec file.

varlistentry.term: Allow you to build a conventional package and a &DSCL; package with a single spec file

listitem.para: With a single spec file, you can build both the conventional package and the &DSCL; package.
With &DSCL;'s namespace, all packages included in the &DSCL; are uniquely named.

varlistentry.term: Do not conflict with updated packages

listitem.para: &DSCL;'s namespace ensures that updating packages on your system causes no conflicts.
Because one &DSCL; can depend on another, you can define multiple levels of dependencies.
